review:
Comrades, let’s cut through the noise and get to the heart of the matter! Lakat steps forward with a vision: to break the chains of centralized academic publishing and anchor the iterative, collaborative process of science in the Ethereum ecosystem. This is not just another DeFi clone or a token pump — it’s a bold attempt to diversify Ethereum’s utility, bringing the power of open, permissionless collaboration to the world of research and knowledge production.

The project’s architecture is inspired by git, supporting multi-branched, edit-centric publishing. It leverages Ethereum for data anchoring, Ceramic for storage, and Starknet for proofs. The roadmap is clear: build a Rust client, integrate with MediaWiki, and test with real academics. The team is public, the code is open, and the whitepaper is available for all to scrutinize.

But let’s not be blinded by ambition alone! Where is the hard evidence of impact? Where are the metrics showing adoption, usage, or measurable improvement in the Ethereum infrastructure? The application speaks of plans and pivots, but offers little in the way of quantifiable results. The social key recovery feature is promising, but still in development. The roadmap is ambitious, but timelines are slipping — Q3 2024 for the Rust client, yet we’re in Q2 2025 with no clear update.

Sustainability? The application does not address how Lakat will sustain itself beyond grants. There’s no mention of a revenue model, community governance structure, or long-term maintenance plan. This is a glaring omission for any project seeking to build public goods for the many, not the few.

In summary: Lakat is a project with vision and technical depth, but it must deliver evidence, sustainability, and transparency if it wants to earn the trust — and the resources — of the people. The revolution in publishing will not be funded on dreams alone!

strengths.title: Clear Vision for Diversifying Ethereum Utility
strengths.description: Lakat aims to move Ethereum beyond DeFi, anchoring collaborative academic publishing in the network. This is a much-needed expansion of Ethereum’s public good utility.

strengths.title: Open Source and Transparent Development
strengths.description: The project is open-source, with public repositories, a whitepaper, and a visible team. This aligns with the highest standards of community-driven development.

strengths.title: Innovative Technical Architecture
strengths.description: The use of git-inspired branching, proof-of-review consensus, and integration with Ceramic and Starknet demonstrates technical creativity and a commitment to interoperability.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Measurable Outcomes and Metrics
weaknesses.description: The application provides no concrete data on adoption, usage, or impact. There are no KPIs, user numbers, or evidence of real-world traction.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Sustainability and Revenue Model
weaknesses.description: There is no plan for how the project will sustain itself beyond grant funding. This raises concerns about long-term viability and responsible stewardship of resources.

weaknesses.title: Roadmap Slippage and Lack of Updates
weaknesses.description: The roadmap is outdated, with promised deliverables (e.g., Rust client) not clearly accounted for as of Q2 2025. This undermines confidence in execution.

changes.title: Provide Quantitative Evidence of Impact
changes.description: Submit clear metrics: number of users, branches created, academic institutions onboarded, or any measurable outcomes since project inception.

changes.title: Detail a Sustainability and Governance Plan
changes.description: Articulate how Lakat will sustain itself post-grant: revenue models, community governance, and long-term maintenance strategies.

changes.title: Update Roadmap and Deliverables
changes.description: Present an up-to-date roadmap with realistic timelines, milestones, and evidence of progress on key deliverables.
